steps.title: Cardiology
steps.text: Multiple Choice for Primary Level Care

steps.title: Acute rheumatic fever & rheumatic heart disease
steps.text: A 10-year-old child presents at a health centre with fever, swollen joints, and a history of sore throat 3 weeks ago. On examination, there is a new heart murmur. What is the most appropriate immediate action at the primary care level?

textChoices.text: Start ibuprofen and oral penicillin, monitor for 48 hours, then refer if no improvement
Give a stat IM dose of benzathine penicillin, start ibuprofen, and refer the patient
Stabilize the patient, give a stat dose of IM benzathine penicillin, and refer to a higher-level facility
Refer immediately to tertiary care without giving treatment to avoid masking symptoms

steps.title: Myocarditis
steps.text: What is the most appropriate management step for suspected myocarditis at the primary care level ?

textChoices.text: Start corticosteroids immediately
Order an echocardiogram and monitor at the facility
Stabilize the patient and refer to a higher-level facility
Begin long-term heart failure medications

steps.title: Dilated Cardiomyopathy
steps.text: What is the correct management approach for a child presenting with signs suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy at the primary care level?

textChoices.text: Start long-term heart failure medication and monitor
Administer corticosteroids and observe
Stabilize the patient and refer to higher-level care
Delay intervention until echocardiography is available

steps.title: Pulmonary hypertension
steps.text: What is the most appropriate course of action at the primary care level when a child is suspected to have pulmonary hypertension?

textChoices.text: Start vasodilators and observe response
Begin diuretics and discharge if improved
Stabilize the patient and refer for pulmonologist and/or cardiologist review
Delay referral until heart failure develops

steps.title: Congenital Heart diseases
steps.text: What is the appropriate course of action at the primary care level for a neonate suspected to have congenital heart disease?

textChoices.text: Start heart failure medications and monitor
Perform chest X-ray and defer referral
Stabilize using ABCDE approach and refer to secondary care
Begin CPAP and provide long-term follow-up

steps.title: Hypercyanotic Spell in Tetralogy of Fallot
steps.text: Why is a child with a hypercyanotic spell placed in a knee–chest position or held on the caregiver’s shoulder with knees tucked?

textChoices.text: To reduce pulmonary pressure and increase heart rate
To calm the child and improve airway patency
To increase systemic venous return and increase systemic vascular resistance
To promote deeper breathing and increase oxygen uptake

steps.title: Hypercyanotic Spell in Tetralogy of Fallot
steps.text: A child with Tetralogy of Fallot presents with a cyanotic spell. Which of the following interventions can be performed at the primary level to support stabilization?

textChoices.text: IV propranolol and morphine
Knee–chest position, 100% oxygen, and fluid bolus (RL or NS 20 ml/kg)
Transfer immediately without intervention
Administer corticosteroids and diuretics

steps.title: Hypercyanotic Spell in Tetralogy of Fallot
steps.text: A child with Tetralogy of Fallot is having a hypercyanotic spell and remains poorly perfused after initial stabilization. According to the guideline, how should fluid resuscitation be administered at the primary care level?

textChoices.text: 10 ml/kg over 1 hour, repeat once if needed
20 ml/kg rapid IV bolus over 30 minutes, repeat once if no improvement (maximum 2 boluses)
Continuous maintenance fluids only
30 ml/kg over 15 minutes, repeat up to 3 times

steps.title: Congestive Heart Failure
steps.text: A 1-year-old presents with signs of congestive heart failure. What is the most appropriate action at the primary care level?

textChoices.text: Start long-term diuretics and monitor for 72 hours
Stabilize using ABCDE, give a stat dose of furosemide if available
Begin oxygen and corticosteroids, then discharge
Refer immediately without providing any treatment

steps.title: Supraventricular Tachycardia
steps.text: A 5-year-old presents with a rapid heart rate (>220 bpm), is alert but appears fatigued. What is the appropriate approach at the primary care level?

textChoices.text: Administer IV adenosine immediately
Perform synchronized cardioversion
Stabilize using ABCDE approach and consult/refer to secondary care
Start oral beta-blockers and monitor for 12 hours

steps.title: Chest Pain
steps.text: Which aspect of history is most important to assess in a child presenting with chest pain?

textChoices.text: Duration, intensity, location, and radiation of pain
Family history of asthma or eczema
Recent antibiotic use
Sleep quality and school performance

steps.title: Chest Pain
steps.text: According to primary care guidelines, which of the following warrants referral of a child with chest pain to a secondary facility?

textChoices.text: Chest pain that worsens with deep breathing
Tenderness on palpation of the chest wall
Occasional complaints of mild pain at rest
Pain worsened by physical activity or abnormal cardiac exam
